newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE Euroyen futures end subdued trade unchanged.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE Euroyen futures end subdued trade unchanged.

text.p: Key December three-month Euroyen interest rate futures closed a subdued day session unchanged on Tuesday with their topside capped by firmness in Tokyo stocks.
A lack of activity meant there was no reaction to the record high in yen cash bond prices or to a rise in Japan's machinery orders in January, traders said.
"We are not interested in what happened in the past," said a dealer at a long-term credit bank.

The Economic Planning Agency said private machinery orders rose 11.8 percent in January from December. But machinery orders in the January-March period are seen falling 8.5 percent from the previous quarter, the EPA said.
"What we want to know is if the economy will slow down after April or not," the dealer said.
From this point of view, little attention is likely to be paid on Japan's gross domestic product (GDP) data for the October-December period due on Thursday, he said.
"You needed a microscope to watch market activity today," said a city bank dealer.
The December settled at 99.19 after moving between 99.18 and 99.19. Turnover was a small 11,642 lots.
The contract failed to rise despite Tuesday's rally in long-term cash bonds, with the key 182nd 10-year Japanese government bond yield falling to a record low 2.315 percent.
"We wouldn't be surprised unless the key bond yield dipped below 2.3 percent," the city bank dealer said.
Short-term money market rates were steady firmer after the central bank conducted a neutral operation for a second day.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) offset a market shortfall of an estimated 100 billion yen by injecting 100 billion yen.

Although such an operation was expected, the key overnight interbank rate jumped to 0.51 percent from Monday's 0.49 and the benchmark three-month certificate of deposit (CD) rate rose to 0.55 percent, the highest level since August last year.
"Those who were in a hurry to raise funds covering the fiscal year-end should be blamed," said another city bank dealer. "Such banks had expected the BOJ to help them out."

Upward pressure in money market rates remained high across the yield curve despite the BOJ's late morning offer to supply funds worth a total of 900 billion yen covering the fiscal year-end, traders said. -- Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-33432-8570
